head.title: Structure and rheology of binary mixtures in shear flow

article.h1: Structure and rheology of binary mixtures in shear flow

span.span: Istituto Nazionale per la Fisica della Materia, Unità di Salerno and Dipartimento di Fisica, Universitá di Salerno, 84081 Baronissi (Salerno), Italy.

Istituto Nazionale per la Fisica della Materia, Unità di Bari and Dipartimento di Fisica, Università di Bari, and Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Bari, via Amendola 173, 70126 Bari, Italy.

div.p: Results are presented for the phase separation process of a binary mixture subject to an uniform shear flow quenched from a disordered to a homogeneous ordered phase. The kinetics of the process is described in the context of the time-dependent Ginzburg-Landau equation with an external velocity term. The large-n𝑛italic-nn approximation is used to study the evolution of the model in the presence of a stationary flow and in the case of an oscillating shear.

For stationary flow we show that the structure factor obeys a generalized dynamical scaling. The domains grow with different typical lengthscales Rxsubscript𝑅𝑥italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{x} and R⟂subscript𝑅perpendicular-toitalic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{\perp} respectively in the flow direction and perpendicularly to it. In the scaling regime R⟂∼tα⟂similar-tosubscript𝑅perpendicular-tosuperscript𝑡subscript𝛼perpendicular-toitalic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR_{\perp}\sim t^{\alpha_{\perp}} and Rx∼γ⁢tαxsimilar-tosubscript𝑅𝑥𝛾superscript𝑡subscript𝛼𝑥italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to italic-gamma italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR_{x}\sim\gamma t^{\alpha_{x}} (with logarithmic corrections), γ𝛾italic-gamma\gamma being the shear rate, with αx=5/4subscript𝛼𝑥54italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:5 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\alpha_{x}=5/4 and α⟂=1/4subscript𝛼perpendicular-to14italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\alpha_{\perp}=1/4. The excess viscosity Δ⁢ηΔ𝜂Delta italic-eta\Delta\eta after reaching a maximum relaxes to zero as γ-2⁢t-3/2superscript𝛾2superscript𝑡32italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{-2}t^{-3/2}. Δ⁢ηΔ𝜂Delta italic-eta\Delta\eta and other observables exhibit log-time periodic oscillations which can be interpreted as due to a growth mechanism where stretching and break-up of domains cyclically occur.

In the case of an oscillating shear a cross-over phenomenon is observed: Initially the evolution is characterized by the same growth exponents as for a stationary flow. For longer times the phase separating structure cannot align with the oscillating drift and a different regime is entered with an isotropic growth and the same exponents of the case without shear.

The kinetics of phase separation of a disordered system quenched into a multiphase coexistence region has been extensively studied in the last years [1]. The main features of the process are well understood: After an early stage during which ordered domains of the equilibrium phases are formed the segregation proceeds in the late stage by coarsening of ordered regions according to the power law growth R⁢(t)∼tαsimilar-to𝑅𝑡superscript𝑡𝛼italic-R OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR(t)\sim t^{\alpha} for the average domains size. In binary liquids, the existence of several regimes characterized by different exponents α𝛼italic-alpha\alpha, due to the presence of various growth mechanisms, is well established [2]. In these regimes the pair correlation function C⁢(r,t)𝐶𝑟𝑡italic-C OPEN:( italic-r PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(r,t) verifies a dynamical scaling law according to which it can be written as C⁢(r,t)≃f⁢(r/R)similar-to-or-equals𝐶𝑟𝑡𝑓𝑟𝑅italic-C OPEN:( italic-r PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to-or-equals italic-f OPEN:( italic-r MULOP:divide italic-R CLOSE:)C(r,t)\simeq f(r/R), where f⁢(x)𝑓𝑥italic-f OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)f(x) is a scaling function [3].

¿From the theoretical point of view the most relevant progresses have been achieved in the framework of the continuous approach based on the Cahn-Hilliard equation with a Ginzburg-Landau free energy functional, the time dependent Ginzburg-Landau (TDGL) model. Within this approach, which neglects hydrodynamics, the properties of the phase-separation kinetics can be efficiently studied by means of numerical simulations or analytically in the context of approximate theories, among which the so-called large-n𝑛italic-nn limit (one-loop approximation). For a vectorial system with an infinite number of components n𝑛italic-nn, indeed, the TDGL model is exactly soluble. The one-loop approximation is known to provide a mean-field picture of the phase-separation process which captures the essence of the phenomenon at a semi-quantitative level [4].

In this paper we study the process of phase separation in a binary mixture subject to an uniform shear flow. When shear is applied to the system the time evolution is substantially different from that of ordinary spinodal decomposition. We consider both a stationary flow and an oscillating shear.

A stationary flow induces strong deformations of the domains formed after the quench [5, 6, 7], which become anisotropic and stretched along the flow direction. Consequently the growth rate along the flow is larger than in the other directions. In some experiments a power law increase of the typical size of the domains is observed and a value Δ⁢α=αx-α⟂Δ𝛼subscript𝛼𝑥subscript𝛼perpendicular-toDelta italic-alpha RELOP:equals italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta\alpha=\alpha_{x}-\alpha_{\perp} in the range 0.8÷10.81NUMBER:0.8 MULOP:divide NUMBER:10.8\div 1 for the difference between the exponents in the flow and in the shear directions is reported [8, 9]. Two dimensional molecular dynamic simulations find a slightly smaller value [10]. In other experimental realizations, when the shear is strong enough, stringlike domains have been observed to extend macroscopically in the direction of the flow [11] preventing complete phase separation. In general, the scaling behavior of sheared systems is not clearly understood and the very existence of a scaling regime in different experimental systems is questionable.

In a previous paper [12] we have shown that the numerical solution of the one-loop approximation to the TDGL model for phase separation under shear exhibits a generalized scaling symmetry characterized by Δ⁢α=1Δ𝛼1Delta italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\Delta\alpha=1. In the scaling regime the structure factor and other observables exhibit the interesting feature of an oscillatory pattern which can be related to a mechanism of storing and dissipation of elastic energy where domains are stretched and broken cyclically. This new effect has been shown to persist up to the longest available time of our computation and represents the hallmark of a complex dynamical pattern induced by the presence of the shear. In a recent paper Rapapa and Bray [13], by solving asymptotically the one-loop equations, confirmed analytically the existence of a (multi)-scaling symmetry; in the long time limit, however, they do not recover the cyclical pattern described insofar and they infer ’that the observed oscillations are slowly-decaying preasymptotic transients’. Since their solution is obtained in the infinite time limit, then, a reference theory for the description of this remarkable phenomenon is lacking.

Given that the one-loop approximation is a mean-field solution in spirit the natural question of its accuracy for the description of the original model arises. A numerical analysis of the exact TDGL model has been performed recently in [14] where it is shown that the global picture of the one-loop approximation is adequate. In particular the oscillatory pattern is recovered. The existence of a scaling symmetry and the determination of the related exponents, however, has not been clearly established numerically mainly due to finite size effects limitations. The actual value of the growth exponents can be inferred by scaling [13] or renormalization group [14] arguments to be α⟂=1/3subscript𝛼perpendicular-to13italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:3\alpha_{\perp}=1/3, as in the case without shear (we stress the fact that hydrodynamic effects are neglected in this model), and αx=4/3subscript𝛼𝑥43italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:4 MULOP:divide NUMBER:3\alpha_{x}=4/3.

The shear also induces a peculiar rheological behavior. The break-up of the stretched domains liberates an energy which gives rise to an increase Δ⁢ηΔ𝜂Delta italic-eta\Delta\eta of the viscosity [15, 16]. Experiments and simulations show that the excess viscosity Δ⁢ηΔ𝜂Delta italic-eta\Delta\eta reaches a maximum at t=tm𝑡subscript𝑡𝑚italic-t RELOP:equals italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt=t_{m} and then relaxes to smaller values. The maximum of the excess viscosity is expected to occur at a fixed γ⁢t𝛾𝑡italic-gamma italic-t\gamma t and to scale as Δ⁢η⁢(tm)∼γ-νsimilar-toΔ𝜂subscript𝑡𝑚superscript𝛾𝜈Delta italic-eta OPEN:( italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-nu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta\eta(t_{m})\sim\gamma^{-\nu} [6, 8]. Simple scaling arguments predict ν=2/3𝜈23italic-nu RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 MULOP:divide NUMBER:3\nu=2/3 [6], but different values have been reported [8]. All these features are adequately described by the TDGL already at the one-loop level.

In this paper we present a complete scenario of the behavior of the TDGL model for phase separation in a shear flow in the framework of the large-n𝑛italic-nn approximation. The behavior of the system is studied along the whole time history, from the instant of the quench onward, both in the presence of a steady flow and in the case of an oscillating shear where interesting effects are undercovered. Results are presented for two and three dimensional systems.

This paper is schematically divided as follows: In Sec.2 we specify the model and introduce the one-loop approximation that will be studied thoroughly in the following Sections. Section 3 is devoted to the analysis of the behavior of the model subjected to a steady flow. In Sec.4 the dynamics in the presence of an oscillatory shear is considered. In Sec.5 we present a discussion of the results, debate some open problems and draw our conclusions.
The binary mixture is described at equilibrium by a Ginzburg-Landau free-energy

div.p: It is possible to show [17] that the substitution (6) becomes exact in models with a vectorial order parameter when the number n𝑛italic-nn of its components becomes infinite. Since ⟨φ2⟩=S⁢(t)delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝜑2𝑆𝑡OPEN:langle italic-varphi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals italic-S OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)\langle\varphi^{2}\rangle=S(t) does not depend on space, due to translational invariance, the substitution (6) formally linearizes the theory. The large-n𝑛italic-nn limit is a well developed approximation scheme in statistical mechanics which have been applied to different contexts [18]: Its validity and limitations are nowadays rather well understood [19].

div.p: For vectorial systems with n>d𝑛𝑑italic-n RELOP:greater-than italic-dn>d (d𝑑italic-dd is the spatial dimensionality) topological defects are not stable [2]. For large n𝑛italic-nn, therefore, domains of the equilibrium phases are, strictly speaking, absent. Nevertheless, since from the solution of the one-loop equations presented below it is possible to identify characteristic growing lengths Rx⁢(t)subscript𝑅𝑥𝑡italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R_{x}(t) and R⟂⁢(t)subscript𝑅perpendicular-to𝑡italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R_{\perp}(t) in the flow and in the other directions it is natural to interpret these quantities as the trace of the domains size after the one-loop approximation procedure has been performed. In the following we will always use the word domains in this broad acception.
In this section we consider the case of a constant shear rate γ𝛾italic-gamma\gamma. Eq. (7) can be formally integrated, yielding

section.h3: III.1 Analytic solution in the short and long time limit

div.p: The consistency condition (8) cannot be worked out along the whole time history of the system. For this reason in the following Sections the model Equations will be solved numerically both in d=2𝑑2italic-d RELOP:equals NUMBER:2d=2 and d=3𝑑3italic-d RELOP:equals NUMBER:3d=3. However the model can be solved in the short and long time limit.

For short times the linearized theory developed originally by Cahn and Hilliard [20] for the situation with γ=0𝛾0italic-gamma RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\gamma=0 can be extended to the present case. This amounts to neglecting the quartic term in the local part of the free energy (1) since in the initial high temperature state the order parameter is small. With this approximation the solution of Eq. (2) reads

semantics.annotation: italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals Delta italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end caligraphic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-z CLOSE:) OPEN:[ caligraphic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-z CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:] italic-d italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 italic-T INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end caligraphic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-z CLOSE:) italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end caligraphic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-s CLOSE:) OPEN:[ caligraphic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-s CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:] italic-d italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-z

div.p: This approach applies to the original model and to the large-n𝑛italic-nn approximation as well because non-linear terms are neglected. It is well known that the linear theory describes the very initial transient of the phase-separation process, when domains are still forming. In this time domain the behaviour of the system in the presence of the flow is more interesting than in the simple case of an immobile fluid. A plot of the structure factor (15) is presented for a two-dimensional system in Fig. (1) for the case γ=1𝛾1italic-gamma RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\gamma=1 and T=0𝑇0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0. Initially, when domains are forming but the shear flow has not yet produced sensible effects, the structure factor evolves assuming the typical structure of a circular volcano, similarly to what happens in the case without shear. At γ⁢t≃0.5similar-to-or-equals𝛾𝑡0.5italic-gamma italic-t RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:0.5\gamma t\simeq 0.5 the anisotropy induced by the shear produces a deformation in the profile of the edge of the volcano from a ring-like geometry into an ellipse, whose major axis forms with the positive direction of the kysubscript𝑘𝑦italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:endk_{y} axis an angle of approximatively 45osuperscript45𝑜NUMBER:45 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end45^{o} (see Fig. (1)). At the same time small dips start to develop in the edge at the ends of the axes of the ellipse and four peaks can be clearly observed at γ⁢t≃2similar-to-or-equals𝛾𝑡2italic-gamma italic-t RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:2\gamma t\simeq 2. As time goes by, the angle formed by the major axis of the ellipse with the kysubscript𝑘𝑦italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:endk_{y}-direction decreases and the dips in the profile of C⁢(k→,t)𝐶→𝑘𝑡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) along the major axis develop until C⁢(k→,t)𝐶→𝑘𝑡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) almost consists of two separated foils, at γ⁢t≃4similar-to-or-equals𝛾𝑡4italic-gamma italic-t RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:4\gamma t\simeq 4, when a couple of peaks prevails. The same initial pattern is also observed [14] by numerically solving the full model equation (2). At later times, however, the presence of the non-linear terms becomes fundamental and the linear theory breaks down, as in the case without shear. It is important to stress the fact that the presence of four peaks in the structure factor is exhibited already at the linear theory level of approximation. We will see in the following sections that the very existence of a multiply peaked C⁢(k→,t)𝐶→𝑘𝑡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) produces a rich dynamical pattern originating an oscillatory phenomenon.

The self-consistency condition (8) has been worked out explicitly in the long-time domain in [13]. It is found that the model is interested by a multiscaling symmetry, as in the case without shear [21], characterized by the growth of the characteristic lengthscales as

semantics.annotation: italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to italic-gamma OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm italic-t ARG:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: and

semantics.annotation: italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-t ARG:end ARG:start OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm italic-t ARG:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: in the directions of the flow and perpendicular to it respectively. The excess viscosity and the normal stress differences behave as

semantics.annotation: Delta italic-eta OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm italic-t ARG:end ARG:start italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

Delta italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to Delta italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm italic-t ARG:end ARG:start italic-t ARG:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: The same behaviors (apart from logarithmic corrections) is obtained in [12] by means of a scaling ansatz.

We present in this Section the results of the numerical integration of the large-n𝑛italic-nn equation (7) which allows to follow the whole time history of the phase-separation process. We restrict ourselves to the case with T=0𝑇0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0. An Euler first order discretization scheme has been implemented in d=2𝑑2italic-d RELOP:equals NUMBER:2d=2 and d=3𝑑3italic-d RELOP:equals NUMBER:3d=3 on d𝑑italic-dd-dimensional lattices with 201201NUMBER:201201 mesh points per each direction. For long times the structure factor is strongly peaked around typical wavevectors which move towards zero as time goes on (see Fig 2). Given that the support of C⁢(k→,t)𝐶→𝑘𝑡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) also shrinks to zero it is possible to greatly improve the quality of the numerical computation by using a self-adaptive mesh algorithm that follows the evolution of the support of the structure factor. We have solved Eq. (7) for various values of the shear rate γ𝛾italic-gamma\gamma in the range [10-4,10-2]superscript104superscript102OPEN:[ NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:][10^{-4},10^{-2}]. We found that the qualitative behavior is the same for all the values of γ𝛾italic-gamma\gamma considered. ¿From the knowledge of the structure factor we compute the characteristic lengths R⁢(t)𝑅𝑡italic-R OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R(t) as

semantics.annotation: italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-square-root ARG:start OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:end ARG:end

div.p: where

semantics.annotation: OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start INTOP:integral italic-d OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start INTOP:integral italic-d OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) ARG:end

div.p: and the same for the other directions.

The behavior of C⁢(k→,t)𝐶→𝑘𝑡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) is shown in Fig. (2) for γ=0.001𝛾0.001italic-gamma RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.001\gamma=0.001. Initially the evolution of the structure factor is resemblant to the one observed in Fig. (1) where the linear theory for C⁢(k→,t)𝐶→𝑘𝑡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) was plotted. Later on, however, the linear theory fails because the non-linearities become relevant, and the long-time regime is entered. This is characterized by the shrinking of the support of C⁢(k→,t)𝐶→𝑘𝑡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) towards the origin with different rates for the shear and the flow directions so that the tilt angle, namely the direction along which C𝐶italic-CC is aligned, decreases in time. The structure factor is divided into two separated foils which are symmetric due to the property C⁢(k→,t)=C⁢(-k→,t)𝐶→𝑘𝑡𝐶→𝑘𝑡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-C OPEN:( ADDOP:minus OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t)=C(-\vec{k},t). In each foil two distinct peaks can be observed located at (kx1,ky1)subscript𝑘subscript𝑥1subscript𝑘subscript𝑦1OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(k_{x_{1}},k_{y_{1}}) and (kx2,ky2)subscript𝑘subscript𝑥2subscript𝑘subscript𝑦2OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(k_{x_{2}},k_{y_{2}}) with |kx1|≃2⁢|kx2|similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑘subscript𝑥12subscript𝑘subscript𝑥2VERTBAR:| italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:2 VERTBAR:| italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:||k_{x_{1}}|\simeq 2|k_{x_{2}}| and |ky1|≃2⁢|ky2|similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑘subscript𝑦12subscript𝑘subscript𝑦2VERTBAR:| italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:2 VERTBAR:| italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:||k_{y_{1}}|\simeq 2|k_{y_{2}}|. Their heights change in time. The first peak to prevail is that located at (kx1,ky1)subscript𝑘subscript𝑥1subscript𝑘subscript𝑦1OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(k_{x_{1}},k_{y_{1}}), while the other peak dominates later. As time elapses the two peaks are observed to prevail alternatively. This oscillatory behavior continues up to the longest times of our computations.

In Fig. (3) the quantities (γ⁢ln⁡t)1/4⁢Rx⁢(t)superscript𝛾𝑡14subscript𝑅𝑥𝑡OPEN:( italic-gamma OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)(\gamma\ln t)^{1/4}R_{x}(t) and (γ⁢ln⁡t)1/4⁢Ry⁢(t)superscript𝛾𝑡14subscript𝑅𝑦𝑡OPEN:( italic-gamma OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)(\gamma\ln t)^{1/4}R_{y}(t) are plotted against the strain γ⁢t𝛾𝑡italic-gamma italic-t\gamma t. According to Eqs.(16,17) for long times these quantities should collapse, for different values of the shear, on two power-law mastercurves with exponents 5/454NUMBER:5 MULOP:divide NUMBER:45/4 and 1/414NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:41/4, respectively. Here we observe that the collapse is indeed good, but the predicted power-law behavior is modulated by an oscillatory pattern. These oscillations are observed to be periodic on a log-time axis and persist up to the limit of the computational time.

We now consider the rheological behavior of the mixture by plotting in Fig. (4) the quantity (γ/ln⁡t)1/2⁢Δ⁢η⁢(t)superscript𝛾𝑡12Δ𝜂𝑡OPEN:( italic-gamma MULOP:divide OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Delta italic-eta OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)(\gamma/\ln t)^{1/2}\Delta\eta(t) against the strain. This quantity reaches a maximum at γ⁢t≃3.5similar-to-or-equals𝛾𝑡3.5italic-gamma italic-t RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:3.5\gamma t\simeq 3.5 and then decrease as also found in experiments [8]. For long times Eq. (18) would predict a data collapse for different γ𝛾italic-gamma\gamma on a single power-law master-curve with exponent -3/232ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2-3/2. Here the situation is similar to the previous figure, in that the predicted behavior is modulated by log-time periodic oscillations. On the bases of simple scaling arguments the maximum of the excess viscosity Δ⁢η⁢(tm)Δ𝜂subscript𝑡𝑚Delta italic-eta OPEN:( italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\Delta\eta(t_{m}) is expected to occur at a fixed γ⁢t𝛾𝑡italic-gamma italic-t\gamma t and to scale as Δ⁢η⁢(tm)∼γ-νsimilar-toΔ𝜂subscript𝑡𝑚superscript𝛾𝜈Delta italic-eta OPEN:( italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-nu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta\eta(t_{m})\sim\gamma^{-
u}, with ν=2/3𝜈23italic-nu RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 MULOP:divide NUMBER:3
u=2/3 [6, 8]. These arguments do not directly apply to the one-loop approximation since, due to the mean field nature, the exponents are different. The asymptotic solution (18) is not adequate to this early stage effect. The γ𝛾italic-gamma\gamma dependence of Δ⁢η⁢(tm)Δ𝜂subscript𝑡𝑚Delta italic-eta OPEN:( italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\Delta\eta(t_{m}) is plotted in the inset of Fig. 4 showing that a power-law behaviour with ν≃0.6similar-to-or-equals𝜈0.6italic-nu RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:0.6
u\simeq 0.6 is obeyed, in partial agreement with the aforementioned scaling arguments.

In Fig. (5) we report the numerical results for the first normal stress by plotting (γ⁢ln⁡t)-1/2⁢Δ⁢N1superscript𝛾𝑡12Δsubscript𝑁1OPEN:( italic-gamma OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Delta italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end(\gamma\ln t)^{-1/2}\Delta N_{1} against γ⁢t𝛾𝑡italic-gamma italic-t\gamma t with γ=0.01𝛾0.01italic-gamma RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.01\gamma=0.01. We find that Δ⁢N1⁢(t)Δsubscript𝑁1𝑡Delta italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)\Delta N_{1}(t) scales asymptotically as predicted by Eq. (19) again modulated by an oscillatory pattern.

The periodic oscillations observed in all the physical observables are due to the competition between the different peaks of C⁢(k→,t)𝐶→𝑘𝑡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t). Let’s refer to the behavior of the excess viscosity to understand how this competition affects the rheological quantities, using the features of the structure factor to obtain information about the domains evolution under the action of shear. Δ⁢ηΔ𝜂Delta italic-eta\Delta\eta reaches its first maximum when the shape of C⁢(k→,t)𝐶→𝑘𝑡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) is such that the peak located at (kx1,ky1)subscript𝑘subscript𝑥1subscript𝑘subscript𝑦1OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(k_{x_{1}},k_{y_{1}}) prevails and the difference between the height of the two peaks is maximal. At this time the domains are elongated by the flow and there is a prevalence of thin domains in the system. As these string-like domains are stretched further, they eventually break up into two or more domains, dissipating the stored energy. This has two effects: the excess viscosity decreases and, on the other hand, the thick domains, which have not yet been broken, prevail. In this situation the other peak of C⁢(k→,t)𝐶→𝑘𝑡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) (which is located at (kx2,ky2)subscript𝑘subscript𝑥2subscript𝑘subscript𝑦2OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(k_{x_{2}},k_{y_{2}}) and represents the smaller features) grows faster until it prevails and Δ⁢ηΔ𝜂Delta italic-eta\Delta\eta reaches a minimum. This behavior is reproduced with a characteristic frequency in log-time. Recently, a similar behavior has been observed in the numerical simulation of the full model Equation (2) [14].

In this section we report the result of the numerical solution of Eq. (7) in d=3𝑑3italic-d RELOP:equals NUMBER:3d=3. In Fig. (6) the time evolution of the structure factor in the special planes kx=0subscript𝑘𝑥0italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0k_{x}=0, ky=0subscript𝑘𝑦0italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0k_{y}=0 and kz=0subscript𝑘𝑧0italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0k_{z}=0 is shown for γ=0.001𝛾0.001italic-gamma RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.001\gamma=0.001. In the plane kz=0subscript𝑘𝑧0italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0k_{z}=0 C⁢(k→,t)𝐶→𝑘𝑡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) behaves analogously to the previously discussed two dimensional case. The structure factor on the plane ky=0subscript𝑘𝑦0italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0k_{y}=0 gives information relative to the observation of the system along the shear direction: No velocity gradient is present in the plane perpendicular to this orientation, but there are different velocities in the x𝑥italic-xx and z𝑧italic-zz directions. This allows to explain the observed behavior which is rather different from the one observed at kz=0subscript𝑘𝑧0italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0k_{z}=0. The structure factor develops initially a circular volcano, as without shear. The edge of the volcano is progressively deformed by the shear into an ellipse with the major axis along the kzsubscript𝑘𝑧italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:endk_{z} direction. The dips in the edge of the volcano at values of kx≃0similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑘𝑥0italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:0k_{x}\simeq 0 develop with time so that at γ⁢t≃1similar-to-or-equals𝛾𝑡1italic-gamma italic-t RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:1\gamma t\simeq 1, C⁢(k→,t)𝐶→𝑘𝑡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) is made of two foils but these are not completely separated. During the time evolution the axes of the ellipse shrink; the decrease is faster along the kxsubscript𝑘𝑥italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endk_{x} direction. The two foils are never completely separated and the angle formed with the kzsubscript𝑘𝑧italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:endk_{z} direction is zero, as observed in experiments [9]. At γ⁢t≃5similar-to-or-equals𝛾𝑡5italic-gamma italic-t RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:5\gamma t\simeq 5 two well-formed peaks start to develop and grow on each foil of C⁢(k→,t)𝐶→𝑘𝑡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t). These four peaks have the same height and their relative heights do not change in time, as it can be seen at γ⁢t=20𝛾𝑡20italic-gamma italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:20\gamma t=20 in the picture, differently from the situation on the kz=0subscript𝑘𝑧0italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0k_{z}=0 plane.

In the kx=0subscript𝑘𝑥0italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0k_{x}=0 plane the shear has no effect at all and the structure factor remains circular during its evolution.

The computed behavior of Rx⁢(t)subscript𝑅𝑥𝑡italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R_{x}(t) and Ry⁢(t)subscript𝑅𝑦𝑡italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R_{y}(t) is similar to that of the two-dimensional case. We also find Rz⁢(t)∼Ry⁢(t)similar-tosubscript𝑅𝑧𝑡subscript𝑅𝑦𝑡italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R_{z}(t)\sim R_{y}(t), as expected.

We report in Fig. (7) the plots of (γ/ln⁡t)1/2⁢Δ⁢η⁢(t)superscript𝛾𝑡12Δ𝜂𝑡OPEN:( italic-gamma MULOP:divide OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Delta italic-eta OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)(\gamma/\ln t)^{1/2}\Delta\eta(t), (γ⁢ln⁡t)-1/2⁢Δ⁢N1⁢(t)superscript𝛾𝑡12Δsubscript𝑁1𝑡OPEN:( italic-gamma OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Delta italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)(\gamma\ln t)^{-1/2}\Delta N_{1}(t) and -(γ⁢ln⁡t)-1/2⁢Δ⁢N2⁢(t)superscript𝛾𝑡12Δsubscript𝑁2𝑡ADDOP:minus OPEN:( italic-gamma OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Delta italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)-(\gamma\ln t)^{-1/2}\Delta N_{2}(t) as functions of γ⁢t𝛾𝑡italic-gamma italic-t\gamma t. It appears that the rheological quantities still have amplitudes which are modulated by log-time oscillations which are in phase among them. The origin of such oscillations has to be found again in the oscillations of the peaks of the structure factor in the plane kz=0subscript𝑘𝑧0italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0k_{z}=0. Since the support of C⁢(k→,t)𝐶→𝑘𝑡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) shrinks towards the origin faster in the kzsubscript𝑘𝑧italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:endk_{z} than in the kysubscript𝑘𝑦italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:endk_{y} direction the second normal stress difference Δ⁢N2⁢(t)Δsubscript𝑁2𝑡Delta italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)\Delta N_{2}(t) is negative. This is in accordance with general experimental experience [22].
In this Section we consider the case of a time-dependent shear rate with

semantics.annotation: italic-gamma OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-omega italic-t

div.p: This situation is of great experimental relevance expecially for probing the viscoelastic properties of the phase separating binary mixture.

We solved the Eq. (7) numerically in d=2𝑑2italic-d RELOP:equals NUMBER:2d=2 using the same numerical scheme as in the case of steady shear, for different values of γ0subscript𝛾0italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\gamma_{0} and ω𝜔italic-omega\omega. We will describe below the case γ0=10-3subscript𝛾0superscript103italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma_{0}=10^{-3}, τ=2⁢π/ω=6×103𝜏2𝜋𝜔6superscript103italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-pi MULOP:divide italic-omega RELOP:equals NUMBER:6 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\tau=2\pi/\omega=6\times 10^{3}. The time evolution of the structure factor in the first cycle of γ⁢(t)𝛾𝑡italic-gamma OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)\gamma(t) is shown in Fig. (8). The dynamical pattern is analogous to the one with γ=c⁢o⁢n⁢s⁢t.𝛾𝑐𝑜𝑛𝑠𝑡italic-gamma RELOP:equals italic-c italic-o italic-n italic-s italic-t PERIOD:.\gamma=const. for times t<τ/4𝑡𝜏4italic-t RELOP:less-than italic-tau MULOP:divide NUMBER:4t<\tau/4 as it can be seen at γo⁢t=1.5subscript𝛾𝑜𝑡1.5italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.5\gamma_{o}t=1.5. Then the time dependent velocity field modifies the behaviour of the blend with respect to the case of a steady flow. In particular, at the end of the first oscillation, the four peaks of C⁢(k→,t)𝐶→𝑘𝑡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) are located at comparable distances from the origin of the k𝑘italic-kk-space differently from what observed in Fig. (2) at γ⁢t=6𝛾𝑡6italic-gamma italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:6\gamma t=6. The two highest maxima at γ0⁢t=6subscript𝛾0𝑡6italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:6\gamma_{0}t=6 in Fig. (8) are characterized by |ky|≫|kx|much-greater-thansubscript𝑘𝑦subscript𝑘𝑥VERTBAR:| italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:much-greater-than VERTBAR:| italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:||k_{y}|\gg|k_{x}|. During the later time evolution these peaks grow and move towards the origin. The position in the k𝑘italic-kk-plane of the other peaks rotates back and forth cyclically along an approximatively circular path. The radius of this trajectory shrinks towards the origin at a rate comparable with that of the position of the other peaks. In the asymptotic regime the four peaks have approximatively the same height and the cyclical rotation of the peak position persists. This is shown in Fig. (9) where the configurations of the structure factor are shown at each quarter of oscillation of the shear rate in the asymptotic stage.

In Fig. (10) the evolution of the characteristic lengths Rx⁢(t)subscript𝑅𝑥𝑡italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R_{x}(t), Ry⁢(t)subscript𝑅𝑦𝑡italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R_{y}(t) is plotted against γ0⁢tsubscript𝛾0𝑡italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t\gamma_{0}t. We also plot, in the inset, the time average of these quantities over a period τ𝜏italic-tau\tau, in order to smoothen out the superimposed oscillations. Here we observe, for times t<τ𝑡𝜏italic-t RELOP:less-than italic-taut<\tau, growth laws analogous to the steady shear case, namely Rx⁢(t)∼t5/4similar-tosubscript𝑅𝑥𝑡superscript𝑡54italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR_{x}(t)\sim t^{5/4} and Ry⁢(t)∼t1/4similar-tosubscript𝑅𝑦𝑡superscript𝑡14italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR_{y}(t)\sim t^{1/4}. The growth exponent of Rxsubscript𝑅𝑥italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{x} changes smoothly, from t≃τsimilar-to-or-equals𝑡𝜏italic-t RELOP:similar-to-or-equals italic-taut\simeq\tau onward, from 5/454NUMBER:5 MULOP:divide NUMBER:45/4 to the asymptotic value 1/414NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:41/4 which is reached at γo⁢t∼80similar-tosubscript𝛾𝑜𝑡80italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:80\gamma_{o}t\sim 80 when all the four peaks of the structure factor have the same height. The gradual crossover of αxsubscript𝛼𝑥italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\alpha_{x} from 5/454NUMBER:5 MULOP:divide NUMBER:45/4 to 1/414NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:41/4 can be better observed for larger values of τ𝜏italic-tau\tau, since the regime with αx=5/4subscript𝛼𝑥54italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:5 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\alpha_{x}=5/4 persists for a longer time. This is shown in Fig. (11), where the evolution of Rx⁢(t)subscript𝑅𝑥𝑡italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R_{x}(t), Ry⁢(t)subscript𝑅𝑦𝑡italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R_{y}(t) is plotted against γ0⁢tsubscript𝛾0𝑡italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t\gamma_{0}t for τ=5×105𝜏5superscript105italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\tau=5\times 10^{5}. For small τ𝜏italic-tau\tau, instead, Rxsubscript𝑅𝑥italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{x} and Rysubscript𝑅𝑦italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{y} grow with the same exponent 1/414NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:41/4 from the beginning.

These observations suggest the following physical interpretation: for t<τ/2𝑡𝜏2italic-t RELOP:less-than italic-tau MULOP:divide NUMBER:2t<\tau/2, since γ𝛾italic-gamma\gamma does not change sign, the evolution of the blend is comparable to the case with a constant shear rate. In particular, if τ𝜏italic-tau\tau is sufficiently large to exceed the initial stage when domains are forming, the power growth laws described in Sec. 3 for Rx,R⟂subscript𝑅𝑥subscript𝑅perpendicular-toitalic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{x},R_{\perp} are observed with αx=5/4subscript𝛼𝑥54italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:5 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\alpha_{x}=5/4 and α⟂=1/4subscript𝛼perpendicular-to14italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\alpha_{\perp}=1/4. On timescales much longer then τ𝜏italic-tau\tau, however, the network of the larger domains cannot be efficiently tilted along the flow orientation which changes periodically its sign. This is confirmed by the behaviour of the two peaks with |ky|≫|kx|much-greater-thansubscript𝑘𝑦subscript𝑘𝑥VERTBAR:| italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:much-greater-than VERTBAR:| italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:||k_{y}|\gg|k_{x}| whose position in the k𝑘italic-kk-plane moves toward the origin but does not cross the kx=0subscript𝑘𝑥0italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0k_{x}=0 plane, as it would be the case if the orientation of the domains corresponding to these peaks were reversed. In this situation the difference Δ⁢α=1Δ𝛼1Delta italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\Delta\alpha=1 between the exponents in the flow and shear direction cannot be sustained, because the larger domains are not directed along the flow orientation at all times, and a growth law with the same exponent 1/4 in all the directions is obeyed. It is interesting to notice that the other peaks, which represent smaller domains formed by the break-up of the larger ones, crosses the ky=0subscript𝑘𝑦0italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0k_{y}=0 plane during their rotation every half period of γ𝛾italic-gamma\gamma. This suggests that these features are tilted by the oscillating shear and follow the flow orientation. Then we expect to observe in a real blend two type of domains which respond differently to the oscillations of the flow: a network of large and elongated structures which maintains the orientation imposed during the first half period of γ𝛾italic-gamma\gamma and a multitude of more isotropic features, generated by the break-up of strained regions, which oscillate following the flow.

For studying rheological properties it is customary [23] to introduce a complex viscosity η*≡η′-i⁢η′′superscript𝜂superscript𝜂′𝑖superscript𝜂′′italic-eta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to italic-eta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-i italic-eta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\eta^{*}\equiv\eta^{\prime}-i\eta^{\prime\prime} which is related to the shear stress by

semantics.annotation: italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-eta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-omega italic-t ADDOP:plus italic-eta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-omega italic-t CLOSE:)

div.p: when Eq. (22) holds. It is also useful to consider [24] another representation of the shear stress given by

div.p: The connection between Eqs. (23) and (24) is given by

div.p: and

semantics.annotation: TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-phi RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-eta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-eta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end PERIOD:.

div.p: By defining γ*⁢(t)=γo⁢ei⁢ω⁢tsuperscript𝛾𝑡subscript𝛾𝑜superscript𝑒𝑖𝜔𝑡italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i italic-omega italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}(t)=\gamma_{o}e^{i\omega t}, we can write Eq. (23) as

semantics.annotation: italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-R italic-e OPEN:[ italic-eta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) CLOSE:]

div.p: In order to relate the real and imaginary parts of the viscosity to physical quantities Eq. (23) can be casted as

semantics.annotation: italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-eta italic-gamma OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-G INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma OPEN:( italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-d italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: where η=η′𝜂superscript𝜂′italic-eta RELOP:equals italic-eta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\eta=\eta^{\prime}, G=ω⁢η′′𝐺𝜔superscript𝜂′′italic-G RELOP:equals italic-omega italic-eta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endG=\omega\eta^{\prime\prime} and the identity sin⁡ω⁢t=ω⁢∫0tcos⁡ω⁢t′⁢d⁢t′𝜔𝑡𝜔superscriptsubscript0𝑡𝜔superscript𝑡′𝑑superscript𝑡′TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-omega italic-t RELOP:equals italic-omega INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-omega italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sin\omega t=\omega\int_{0}^{t}\cos\omega t^{\prime}dt^{\prime} has been used.

The coefficient η𝜂italic-eta\eta in the r.h.s. of the Eq. (28) multiplies the portion of the shear stress in phase with the shear rate and represents the viscosity of a viscoelastic fluid. The integral of the second term of the r.h.s. of the Eq. (28) can be identified with the shear strain present in the mixture at time t𝑡italic-tt. The coefficient G𝐺italic-GG is therefore the effective elastic shear modulus of the fluid. Pure viscous behavior corresponds to G=0𝐺0italic-G RELOP:equals NUMBER:0G=0 (ϕ=π/2italic-ϕ𝜋2italic-phi RELOP:equals italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2\phi=\pi/2), pure elastic behavior to η=0𝜂0italic-eta RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\eta=0 (ϕ=0italic-ϕ0italic-phi RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\phi=0) [24].
In order to compute η𝜂italic-eta\eta and G𝐺italic-GG during the phase separation we calculated by numerical integration the shear stress using its general definition (9). By writing

semantics.annotation: italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-A TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-omega italic-t ADDOP:plus italic-B TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-omega italic-t

div.p: it follows that η=A⁢(t)/γo𝜂𝐴𝑡subscript𝛾𝑜italic-eta RELOP:equals italic-A OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\eta=A(t)/\gamma_{o} and G=ω⁢B⁢(t)/γo𝐺𝜔𝐵𝑡subscript𝛾𝑜italic-G RELOP:equals italic-omega italic-B OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:endG=\omega B(t)/\gamma_{o}. In general, A𝐴italic-AA and B𝐵italic-BB depend on time. During a single shear oscillation, however, we expect that the Eq. (29) holds as a good approximation with constant values for A𝐴italic-AA and B𝐵italic-BB. In this way σx⁢y⁢(t)subscript𝜎𝑥𝑦𝑡italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)\sigma_{xy}(t) is expressed in terms of the first two coefficients in a Fourier series expansion over the interval of scaled time of duration 2⁢π2𝜋NUMBER:2 italic-pi2\pi. The values we obtain may be referred to the time that locates the middle of the interval. Thus we get

In Fig. (12) we report the plots of η𝜂italic-eta\eta and G𝐺italic-GG against γo⁢tsubscript𝛾𝑜𝑡italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t\gamma_{o}t. The viscosity shows a crossover between a power law decay with exponent -3/232ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2-3/2 at short times and an asymptotic behavior whose exponent is -1/212ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2-1/2. This can be explained observing that, for the steady shear case, the dynamic viscosity η𝜂italic-eta\eta coincides with the excess viscosity which scales with the inverse of the domains volume V𝑉italic-VV. When an oscillatory shear is applied V𝑉italic-VV crosses over from an initial power law increase V∼t3/2similar-to𝑉superscript𝑡32italic-V RELOP:similar-to italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV\sim t^{3/2}, similar to the one for the case with steady shear (see Fig. (3)), to a slower growth V∼t1/2similar-to𝑉superscript𝑡12italic-V RELOP:similar-to italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV\sim t^{1/2}, as already discussed above for Rx⁢(t)subscript𝑅𝑥𝑡italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R_{x}(t), producing a corresponding crossover in η𝜂italic-eta\eta.

¿From the computed values of η𝜂italic-eta\eta and G𝐺italic-GG we estimated the phase angle ϕitalic-ϕitalic-phi\phi, which, according to Eqs. (26) and (28), is given by ϕ=arctan⁡(ηG⁢ω)italic-ϕ𝜂𝐺𝜔italic-phi RELOP:equals OPFUNCTION:inverse-tangent OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-eta ARG:end ARG:start italic-G ARG:end italic-omega CLOSE:)\displaystyle\phi=\arctan\Big{(}\frac{\eta}{G}\;\omega\Big{)}. In Fig. (13) we report the time evolution of ϕitalic-ϕitalic-phi\phi as a function of γo⁢tsubscript𝛾𝑜𝑡italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t\gamma_{o}t. It can be seen that ϕitalic-ϕitalic-phi\phi decreases with time to reach an asymptotic value which is approximately 0.016. Accordingly, the system we are investigating shows in the asymptotic stage a behavior which is essentially elastic. The experimental data of [25] confirm this behavior.

In this paper we have studied the kinetics of a phase-separating binary fluid, in the presence of a shear flow, by means of the TDGL model. It is nowadays well established that the corresponding model with γ=0𝛾0italic-gamma RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\gamma=0 accurately describes the main features of the segregation process in binary alloys, where hydrodynamics can be neglected. In viscous fluids, such as polymeric blends, the validity of the present approach is limited to the early stage of spinodal decomposition; for longer times one should consider the full hydrodynamic description [2].

When the shear is applied to a fluid the behavior of the system is profoundly changed under many respects and a general agreement on the predictivness of the proposed models is matter of general debate. A discussion on possible effects of hydrodynamics is presented in [3]. Moreover, the numerical solution of the TDGL model with shear poses serious problems due to discretization limitations and finite size effects and, although some progresses have been recently achieved [14], a satisfactory description is nowadays not available. In this scenario it is important to devise a simple analytical scheme providing the fundamental tools for the comprehension of the fluid dynamics. A natural choice in the field of growth kinetics is the large-n𝑛italic-nn approximation, that has been thoroughly studied in the case without shear, where it has proven to give a reliable description of the segregation process, although at a mean field level.

In this paper the behavior of the TDGL model in the one-loop approximation is studied in detail, and the whole time evolution of the blend is considered, from the quenching instant onward; the cases of a stationary flow and of an oscillating shear have been examined. In doing so we undercover a very rich dynamical pattern, where not only some experimental findings are reproduced, but new predictions are allowed. After an early stage, which is accurately described by the linear theory á la Cahn-Hilliard, the presence of the velocity field produces an anisotropic power-law growth of the characteristic lengths Rxsubscript𝑅𝑥italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{x}, R⟂subscript𝑅perpendicular-toitalic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{\perp} respectively in the flow direction and perpendicularly to it. The value of the exponent α⟂=1/4subscript𝛼perpendicular-to14italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\alpha_{\perp}=1/4 in the directions perpendicular to the flow is the same as in models with vectorial conserved order parameter without shear; although the actual value of this exponent is not expected to be accurate for real fluids (since, even without shear, the exponent obtained at the same level of approximation is known to corresponds to the Lifshitz-Slyozov exponent α=1/3𝛼13italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:3\alpha=1/3 for scalar fields) a growth exponent α⟂subscript𝛼perpendicular-toitalic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\alpha_{\perp} unaffected by the presence of shear has been obtained also by scaling [13] and renormalization group [14] arguments applied to the full model equations and is also measured in experiments [8]. Moreover a difference Δ⁢α=1Δ𝛼1Delta italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\Delta\alpha=1 between the flow and shear exponents is also expected to be obtained by releasing the present approximation [13, 14] and is observed in some experiments. In the case of a stationary flow the anisotropic growth governed by these exponents is observed from the onset of the scaling regime onwards. The power law behavior of any observable is decorated by log-time periodic oscillations. These oscillations characterize the scaling regime up to the longest simulated time but they are not observed in the asymptotic solution presented in [13]. Given that log-time periodicity appears to be a rather common feature being observed, besides segregating fluids, during fracturing of heterogeneous solids [26, 27] and in stock market indices [28] for instance, it would then be interesting to devise an analytical approach to enlighten the origin of this new phenomenon at least in the present model.

In experiments with real fluid systems carried out by Laufer et al. [29] and, successively, by Mani et al. [30] and Migler et al. [31] a double overshoot in the time behavior of the viscosity and of the normal stress is observed and an interpretation in terms of break-up and recombination of the domains network is proposed. On the bases of our results it is plausible that this double overshoot represents the first part of a log-time periodic phenomenon which could be hopefully detected with a suitable experimental setup. In the model we have studied the oscillatory behaviour is due to the competition between the different maxima of a four-fold peaked structure factor. The presence of these maxima is interpreted is Sec. III B as due to the existence of different types of domains and the recurrent prevalence of each peak is suggested to be caused by the interplay between these kind of regions. A structure factor with four maxima has also been observed in polymer mixtures [31]; however to our knowledge the connection between the alternative dominance of the peaks of C⁢(k→,t)𝐶→𝑘𝑡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) and the overshoots observed in the viscosity and in the stresses has never been discussed insofar, perhaps due to insufficient resolution, although an experimental confirmation of this hypotheses would be desirable.

When an oscillating shear is present, the anisotropic regime discussed so far for the steady shear case crosses over to an isotropic growth when domains are fully developed. In this late stage, from the analysis of the behavior of the structure factor, we conjecture again the existence of two types of domains responding differently to the flow oscillations: the network of elongated structures keeps the orientation assumed during its formation in the early stage while small features generated by scission of strained parts oscillate in phase with the flow. In this late stage the growth kinetics is regulated by the same exponents as without flow. We are not aware of experiments reporting these features: It would be interesting to devise an experimental set-up for testing this prediction.
